metadata.subject: physics
metadata.topicName: Comparing Gravitational, Electric and Magnetic Fields
metadata.dotPoint: investigate and compare theoretically and practically gravitational, magnetic and electric fields, including directions and shapes of fields, attractive and repulsive effects, and the existence of dipoles and monopoles

field_definition.name: Field Definition
field_definition.correct: A field is a region of space where each point is subject to a non-contact force. Fields explain how forces act without physical contact.

region where objects touch.error: That describes contact forces, not fields.
region where objects touch.fix: Fields explain NON-contact forces. Gravity, electric forces, and magnetic forces all act at a distance.
region where objects touch.action: List three examples of non-contact forces that fields explain.

visible area around magnets.error: Fields are not visible. You may be thinking of iron filings showing the field pattern.
visible area around magnets.fix: Fields are invisible regions where forces act. Iron filings make magnetic fields visible but are not the field itself.
visible area around magnets.action: Explain why we use field lines to represent something invisible.

empty space between objects.error: Fields are not empty space. They represent where forces can act.
empty space between objects.fix: A field is a model that describes how forces act at every point in a region, not a description of emptiness.
empty space between objects.action: Consider: how does gravity act on you if space between you and Earth were truly empty?

persistent.gap: You are confusing the field model with direct physical contact.
persistent.action: Draw diagrams of gravitational, electric, and magnetic fields. Label them as models for non-contact forces.

gravitational_field_direction.name: Gravitational Field Direction
gravitational_field_direction.correct: Gravitational field lines always point TOWARD the mass creating the field. A test mass placed in the field would be pulled in the direction of the field lines.

away from the mass.error: Reversed. Gravity pulls IN, not out.
away from the mass.fix: Field lines show the direction a test mass would be pushed or pulled. Gravity only attracts, so lines point toward the source.
away from the mass.action: Draw a mass and ask: which way would a dropped object accelerate?

parallel to the surface.error: That describes uniform fields between plates, not point masses.
parallel to the surface.fix: Point masses create radial fields with lines pointing toward the centre. Parallel fields exist between charged plates.
parallel to the surface.action: Sketch field lines around Earth. They should radiate inward, not run parallel.

in circular paths.error: Confusing field lines with orbital paths.
in circular paths.fix: Field lines show force direction, not object trajectories. Orbits are curved paths IN a field; field lines are straight and radial.
in circular paths.action: Draw field lines (straight, inward) separately from orbital paths (curved, circular).

persistent.gap: You are not visualising gravitational field direction correctly.
persistent.action: Draw 5 point masses with field lines. Every line must point toward the mass, never away.

electric_field_direction.name: Electric Field Direction
electric_field_direction.correct: Electric field lines point AWAY from positive charges and TOWARD negative charges. The direction shows how a positive test charge would move.

toward positive charges.fix: Field direction = direction a POSITIVE test charge would be pushed. Positive repels positive, so field points away from positive source.
toward positive charges.action: Place an imaginary positive test charge near a positive source. Which way is it pushed?

away from negative charges.fix: A positive test charge is attracted TO negative charges. Field points toward negative because that is where positive charge would move.
away from negative charges.action: Place an imaginary positive test charge near a negative source. Which way is it pulled?

always toward the charge.error: That is gravity, not electric fields.
always toward the charge.fix: Electric fields can point either direction depending on the sign of the source charge. Only gravity always attracts.
always toward the charge.action: Key difference: gravity only attracts; electric forces attract AND repel.

persistent.gap: You are confusing electric and gravitational field directions.
persistent.action: Memorise: E-field points away from positive, toward negative. Use a positive test charge to determine direction.

magnetic_field_direction.name: Magnetic Field Direction
magnetic_field_direction.correct: External magnetic field lines run from the north pole to the south pole of a magnet. Inside the magnet, they run south to north to form closed loops.

south to north externally.error: Reversed. External lines go north to south.
south to north externally.fix: Convention: external field lines exit the north pole and enter the south pole. They form closed loops through the magnet.
south to north externally.action: Draw a bar magnet with field lines. Label N and S poles, ensure lines exit N and enter S.

radially outward from centre.error: That describes electric fields from positive charges, not magnetic fields.
radially outward from centre.fix: Magnetic field lines form loops between poles. They are not radial like electric or gravitational fields from point sources.
radially outward from centre.action: Compare: electric field from point charge (radial) vs magnetic field from bar magnet (loops).

only inside the magnet.error: Magnetic fields extend beyond the magnet.
only inside the magnet.fix: Field lines form complete loops. They run externally from N to S, then internally from S to N.
only inside the magnet.action: Sprinkle iron filings around a magnet to see the external field pattern.

persistent.gap: You are confusing magnetic field direction with electric or gravitational fields.
persistent.action: Draw magnetic field patterns for bar magnets, solenoids, and current-carrying wires. Note the loop structure.

radial_field_shape.name: Radial Field Shape
radial_field_shape.correct: Point masses and point charges create radial fields. Lines spread outward (or inward) like spokes of a wheel, equally spaced around the source.

parallel lines.error: Parallel lines are for uniform fields, not point sources.
parallel lines.fix: Point sources create radial patterns. Parallel field lines exist between charged plates or near Earth surface.
parallel lines.action: Compare diagrams: point charge (radial) vs parallel plates (uniform/parallel).

curved lines.error: Single point sources have straight radial lines.
curved lines.fix: Curved field lines appear with multiple sources (like dipoles). A single source produces straight radial lines.
curved lines.action: Draw field from ONE charge (straight lines). Add a second charge and note how lines curve.

concentric circles.error: Circles show equipotential lines or magnetic fields, not electric/gravitational fields from point sources.
concentric circles.fix: Radial field lines are straight. Equipotentials are perpendicular to field lines. Magnetic fields around wires are circular.
concentric circles.action: Distinguish field lines (show force direction) from equipotentials (show constant potential).

persistent.gap: You are confusing field line shapes for different configurations.
persistent.action: Make a table: point source = radial, parallel plates = uniform, dipole = curved, current-carrying wire = circular.

uniform_field_shape.name: Uniform Field Shape
uniform_field_shape.correct: A uniform field has constant magnitude and direction at all points. It is represented by parallel, equally spaced field lines.

radial lines from centre.error: Radial lines indicate non-uniform fields from point sources.
radial lines from centre.fix: Uniform fields have parallel lines. Radial fields from point sources are non-uniform because strength decreases with distance.
radial lines from centre.action: Compare field between parallel plates (uniform) with field around a point charge (non-uniform).

converging lines.error: Converging lines indicate a non-uniform field with varying strength.
converging lines.fix: Uniform fields have constant spacing. Converging or diverging lines show changing field strength.
converging lines.action: Draw a uniform field with ruler to keep lines parallel and equally spaced.

closed loops.error: Closed loops describe magnetic fields, not uniform electric or gravitational fields.
closed loops.fix: Electric and gravitational field lines start and end at charges/masses. Magnetic field lines form loops.
closed loops.action: Identify which field type forms loops (magnetic) vs which terminate at sources (electric/gravitational).

persistent.gap: You are confusing uniform and non-uniform field representations.
persistent.action: Practice drawing uniform fields (parallel plates) and non-uniform fields (point sources). Note spacing and direction.

gravity_attraction.name: Gravitational Attraction
gravity_attraction.correct: Gravitational forces are ALWAYS attractive. There is no gravitational repulsion. All masses attract all other masses.

masses can repel.error: Gravity never repels. This is a key difference from electric and magnetic forces.
masses can repel.fix: Unlike electric charges or magnetic poles, mass only comes in one type. All masses attract each other.
masses can repel.action: Ask: is there such thing as negative mass? No, so gravity cannot repel.

depends on distance.error: Distance affects magnitude, not whether attraction or repulsion occurs.
depends on distance.fix: Gravity is always attractive regardless of distance. Distance only changes how strong the attraction is.
depends on distance.action: Write: gravity is always attractive. Distance affects strength (1/r²), not direction.

depends on mass ratio.error: Mass ratio affects force magnitude, not whether attraction or repulsion occurs.
depends on mass ratio.fix: Any two masses attract each other. The ratio of masses affects how strong the force is, not its direction.
depends on mass ratio.action: Calculate gravitational force between different mass pairs. Note all forces are attractive.

persistent.gap: You are not recognising that gravity is always attractive.
persistent.action: Write out: gravity only attracts, electricity attracts and repels, magnetism attracts and repels. Memorise this distinction.

electric_attraction_repulsion.name: Electric Attraction and Repulsion
electric_attraction_repulsion.correct: Like charges (both positive or both negative) repel each other. Opposite charges (one positive, one negative) attract each other.

like charges attract.fix: Like charges repel, opposite attract. Think of magnets: same poles push apart, opposite poles pull together.
like charges attract.action: Rub two balloons on hair. They both become negatively charged and repel each other.

opposite charges repel.fix: Opposite charges attract. A positive and negative charge pull toward each other.
opposite charges repel.action: Static cling occurs because opposite charges attract. Clothes with opposite charges stick together.

charges always attract.error: That describes gravity, not electric forces.
charges always attract.fix: Electric forces can attract OR repel depending on charge signs. Only gravity is always attractive.
charges always attract.action: List: gravity = always attract, electric = attract or repel (depends on charge signs).

persistent.gap: You are confusing electric force directions with gravitational forces.
persistent.action: Draw force diagrams for: two positive charges, two negative charges, one positive and one negative. Label attract/repel.

magnetic_attraction_repulsion.name: Magnetic Attraction and Repulsion
magnetic_attraction_repulsion.correct: Like magnetic poles (N-N or S-S) repel each other. Opposite poles (N-S) attract each other. This is analogous to electric charges.

like poles attract.fix: Like poles repel, opposite poles attract. Try pushing two north poles of magnets together; they resist.
like poles attract.action: Experiment with two bar magnets. Note which orientations attract and which repel.

opposite poles repel.fix: Opposite poles attract. North and south poles pull toward each other.
opposite poles repel.action: A compass needle (a small magnet) points toward Earth magnetic south pole because opposites attract.

all poles attract.error: Magnetic forces can be attractive or repulsive depending on pole orientation.
all poles attract.fix: Like gravity, magnetism is a non-contact force. Unlike gravity, magnetism can attract or repel.
all poles attract.action: Compare: gravity always attracts, magnetism attracts OR repels depending on pole orientation.

persistent.gap: You are confusing magnetic pole interactions.
persistent.action: Memorise: like poles repel (N-N, S-S), opposite poles attract (N-S). Same rule as electric charges.

monopole_definition.name: Monopole Definition
monopole_definition.formula: Single source, one type of field line direction
monopole_definition.correct: A monopole is a field source where all field lines point either toward OR away from the source. Point masses and point charges create monopole fields.

two poles close together.error: That describes a dipole, not a monopole.
two poles close together.fix: Mono = one. A monopole has one pole. A dipole has two poles (like a bar magnet with N and S).
two poles close together.action: Draw a single positive charge (monopole) vs a positive-negative pair (dipole).

field with no source.error: All fields have sources. Monopole refers to the type of source.
field with no source.fix: A monopole is a single source creating a radial field. It does not mean no source.
field with no source.action: Identify the source in each case: gravitational monopole = mass, electric monopole = charge.

magnetic north pole alone.error: Isolated magnetic monopoles do not exist in nature.
magnetic north pole alone.fix: You cannot have a magnetic north pole without a south pole. Magnetic monopoles are theoretical; all magnets are dipoles.
magnetic north pole alone.action: Cut a bar magnet in half. Do you get separate N and S poles? No, you get two smaller dipoles.

persistent.gap: You are confusing monopoles with dipoles or misunderstanding what monopole means.
persistent.action: List: gravitational monopoles (masses), electric monopoles (single charges), magnetic monopoles (do not exist naturally).

dipole_definition.name: Dipole Definition
dipole_definition.formula: Two opposite poles, field lines in both directions
dipole_definition.correct: A dipole consists of two opposite poles. Field lines point away from one pole and toward the other. Electric dipoles and magnetic dipoles both exist.

single strong source.error: That describes a monopole, not a dipole.
single strong source.fix: Di = two. A dipole has two poles with opposite properties creating a combined field pattern.
single strong source.action: Draw an electric dipole (+ and − charges) and a magnetic dipole (N and S poles).

two identical sources.error: Dipoles have opposite poles, not identical ones.
two identical sources.fix: A dipole requires opposite poles: +/−, or N/S. Two positive charges create two monopoles, not a dipole.
two identical sources.action: Compare: two positive charges (two monopoles) vs one positive and one negative (dipole).

only exists in magnetism.fix: Both electric and magnetic dipoles exist. An electric dipole has + and − charges; a magnetic dipole has N and S poles.
only exists in magnetism.action: List examples: electric dipole (water molecule), magnetic dipole (bar magnet).

persistent.gap: You are confusing dipoles with monopoles or thinking dipoles are only magnetic.
persistent.action: Draw both an electric dipole and a magnetic dipole. Note both have field lines going in two directions.

magnetic_monopole_nonexistence.name: Magnetic Monopoles Do Not Exist
magnetic_monopole_nonexistence.correct: Isolated magnetic monopoles have never been observed in nature. All magnets have both a north and south pole. Cutting a magnet creates two smaller dipoles.

can be created by cutting magnets.error: Cutting a magnet creates two dipoles, not isolated poles.
can be created by cutting magnets.fix: When you cut a bar magnet, each piece develops its own N and S poles. You cannot isolate a single pole.
can be created by cutting magnets.action: Think about what happens at the atomic level. Each atom is a tiny dipole that aligns.

exist but are rare.error: No magnetic monopoles have ever been observed despite extensive searches.
exist but are rare.fix: Magnetic monopoles are predicted by some theories but have never been found experimentally.
exist but are rare.action: Research the history of magnetic monopole searches. Note that none have succeeded.

only exist in space.error: Magnetic monopoles have not been found anywhere, including space.
only exist in space.fix: Scientists have searched for cosmic magnetic monopoles but found none. All known magnetic objects are dipoles.
only exist in space.action: Compare: electric monopoles (single charges) exist; magnetic monopoles do not.

persistent.gap: You are not recognising that magnetic monopoles do not exist in nature.
persistent.action: Memorise: masses and charges can exist as monopoles; magnetic poles cannot be isolated.

field_model.title: Understanding the Field Model
field_model.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of how fields model non-contact forces.

sentences.text: A field is a region of space where each point is subject to a {{d1}} force. The three types of fields studied in VCE Physics are {{d2}}, electric, and magnetic fields.

d1.tooltip: Fields explain forces that act at a distance

d2.tooltip: Which force keeps planets in orbit?

sentences.text: Field lines are used to visualise fields. The {{d3}} of field lines indicates the direction of the field, and the {{d4}} of field lines indicates the field strength.

d3.tooltip: Arrows on field lines show what property?

d4.tooltip: Closer lines mean stronger field. What property is this?

sentences.text: A field where the magnitude and direction are the same at all points is called a {{d5}} field, represented by {{d6}} field lines.

d6.tooltip: What pattern shows constant field strength and direction?

field_shapes.title: Field Shapes and Directions
field_shapes.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show your understanding of how different fields are represented.

sentences.text: Gravitational field lines around a point mass are {{d1}} and always point {{d2}} the mass, because gravity only attracts.

d1.tooltip: Lines spread out from a point in all directions

sentences.text: Electric field lines point {{d3}} positive charges and {{d4}} negative charges. This is determined by the direction a positive test charge would move.

d3.tooltip: Positive repels positive, so field points which way?

d4.tooltip: Positive is attracted to negative, so field points which way?

sentences.text: Magnetic field lines around a bar magnet form {{d5}} that run from the {{d6}} pole to the {{d7}} pole externally.

d5.tooltip: Magnetic field lines never start or end

attract_repel.title: Attractive and Repulsive Forces
attract_repel.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to demonstrate your understanding of attraction and repulsion in fields.

sentences.text: Gravitational forces between masses are {{d1}} attractive. Unlike electric and magnetic forces, gravity {{d2}} repel.

d1.tooltip: Is there any case where gravity repels?

d2.tooltip: There is no such thing as negative mass

sentences.text: For electric charges, like charges {{d3}} each other while opposite charges {{d4}} each other. This means two negative charges will {{d5}}.

d3.tooltip: What happens when you bring same charges together?

d4.tooltip: What happens when you bring opposite charges together?

sentences.text: Magnetic poles follow the same pattern: like poles {{d6}} and opposite poles {{d7}}. Two north poles brought together will {{d8}}.

d7.tooltip: N and S poles do what?

d8.tooltip: Two north poles are like poles

monopole_dipole.title: Monopoles and Dipoles
monopole_dipole.instructions: Complete the dropdowns to show your understanding of monopole and dipole field sources.

sentences.text: A monopole is a field source where all field lines point {{d1}} direction (either all toward or all away). A single point mass creates a gravitational {{d2}}.
A dipole has {{d3}} poles with field lines pointing in both directions. A bar magnet with north and south poles is a magnetic {{d4}}.
Gravitational and electric monopoles {{d5}} exist in nature. However, magnetic monopoles have {{d6}} been observed; all magnets are {{d7}}.

d5.tooltip: Single masses and single charges exist

d6.tooltip: Has anyone ever found an isolated north or south pole?

d7.tooltip: All magnets have both N and S poles

field_model.title: Applying the Field Model
field_model.instructions: Apply your understanding of fields to practical scenarios.

sentences.text: When a compass is placed near a bar magnet, its needle aligns with the {{d1}}. This demonstrates that the compass experiences a {{d2}} force from the magnet even without touching it.

d1.tooltip: Compasses respond to which type of field?

d2.tooltip: Does the magnet touch the compass to affect it?

sentences.text: In a region where field lines are closer together, the field is {{d3}}. Between two charged parallel plates, the field is {{d4}} because field lines are equally spaced.

d3.tooltip: Closer lines indicate what about field strength?

d4.tooltip: Equal spacing means what about the field?

sentences.text: A static field does not change with {{d5}}. A bar magnet that is not moving produces a {{d6}} magnetic field.

d5.tooltip: Static means not changing over what?

d6.tooltip: If the magnet is stationary, is the field changing?

field_shapes.title: Visualising Field Patterns
field_shapes.instructions: Apply your knowledge to identify and compare field patterns.

sentences.text: A dropped object falls toward Earth because gravitational field lines point {{d1}}. Near Earth surface, the field appears {{d2}} because the lines are approximately parallel.

d1.tooltip: Which way does gravity pull objects?

d2.tooltip: When field lines are parallel, what type of field is it?

sentences.text: If a positive test charge is placed near a negative source charge, it will accelerate {{d3}} the source because the electric field points {{d4}} negative charges.

d4.tooltip: Field direction is where positive test charge moves

sentences.text: The magnetic field around a current-carrying wire forms {{d5}} centred on the wire. This pattern is different from the {{d6}} field of a point charge.

d5.tooltip: What shape is the field around a wire?

d6.tooltip: Point charges create what pattern of field?

attract_repel.title: Predicting Interactions
attract_repel.instructions: Apply the rules of attraction and repulsion to predict field interactions.

sentences.text: Two protons (both positive) will {{d1}} each other electrically. However, they {{d2}} each other gravitationally because masses always attract.

d2.tooltip: What do all masses do to each other?

sentences.text: When the north pole of one magnet approaches the south pole of another, the magnets {{d3}}. If both north poles face each other, they {{d4}}.

d3.tooltip: North and south are opposite poles

d4.tooltip: Two north poles are like poles

sentences.text: The key difference between gravity and the other two fields is that gravity {{d5}} produces repulsion. Electric and magnetic forces can both {{d6}} and {{d7}}.

d5.tooltip: Can gravity ever push objects apart?

d6.tooltip: What can electric and magnetic forces do?

d7.tooltip: The other thing electric and magnetic forces can do

monopole_dipole.title: Identifying Monopoles and Dipoles
monopole_dipole.instructions: Apply your understanding to identify field types in different scenarios.

sentences.text: An electron creates an electric {{d1}} because it has a single negative charge. Its field lines all point {{d2}} the electron.

d2.tooltip: Which way do field lines point for negative charges?

sentences.text: A water molecule has positive and negative regions, making it an electric {{d3}}. A bar magnet with N and S poles is a magnetic {{d4}}.
If you cut a bar magnet in half, you get {{d5}} smaller magnets, each with {{d6}} poles. This demonstrates that magnetic monopoles {{d7}}.

d5.tooltip: How many pieces when you cut something in half?

d7.tooltip: What does this tell us about isolated magnetic poles?

field_model.title: Mastering the Field Model
field_model.instructions: Demonstrate complete understanding of field concepts by addressing common misconceptions.

sentences.text: A common error is thinking fields only exist when we can see them. In reality, fields are {{d1}} models that exist whether or not we use iron filings or other tools to {{d2}} them.

d1.tooltip: Can you see a field directly?

d2.tooltip: Iron filings show the field pattern but do not create the field

sentences.text: Students sometimes confuse field strength with field type. Closer field lines indicate {{d3}} field strength, not a different {{d4}} of field.

d4.tooltip: Gravitational field stays gravitational regardless of strength

sentences.text: The field model explains why the Moon orbits Earth without any physical {{d5}}. Gravity acts through the {{d6}} field that Earth creates in the space around it.

d5.tooltip: Is there a rope connecting Earth and Moon?

d6.tooltip: What type of force keeps the Moon in orbit?

field_shapes.title: Synthesising Field Patterns
field_shapes.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by comparing and contrasting field shapes across all three field types.

sentences.text: Gravitational and electric fields from point sources are both {{d1}}, but they differ in direction: gravitational always points {{d2}}, while electric can point either way depending on {{d3}}.

d1.tooltip: What shape do point source fields have?

d3.tooltip: What determines if electric field points in or out?

sentences.text: Magnetic field lines form {{d4}} that never start or end at a point. This is fundamentally different from electric and gravitational fields, which {{d5}} at their sources.

d4.tooltip: Magnetic field lines have no beginning or end

d5.tooltip: Where do electric/gravitational field lines begin and end?

sentences.text: Between two oppositely charged parallel plates, the electric field is {{d6}} with field lines pointing from {{d7}} plate to {{d8}} plate.

d6.tooltip: What type of field has parallel, equally spaced lines?

d7.tooltip: Field lines point away from which charge?

d8.tooltip: Field lines point toward which charge?

attract_repel.title: Complete Understanding of Field Interactions
attract_repel.instructions: Demonstrate mastery by explaining the fundamental reasons for attraction and repulsion.

sentences.text: The reason gravity only attracts is that mass only comes in {{d1}} type. Charge comes in two types (positive and negative), allowing electric forces to {{d2}}.

d1.tooltip: Is there such thing as negative mass?

d2.tooltip: What can opposite and like charges do?

sentences.text: A common misconception is that a heavy object and a light object have {{d3}} gravitational attraction between them. In fact, both objects attract each other with {{d4}} force magnitude.

d3.tooltip: Does Earth attract you, or do you attract Earth, or both?

d4.tooltip: Newton's third law applies to gravitational forces

sentences.text: Current-carrying wires can {{d5}} or {{d6}} each other depending on current direction. If currents flow in the same direction, the wires {{d7}}.

d5.tooltip: One thing wires can do to each other

d6.tooltip: The other thing wires can do

d7.tooltip: Parallel currents attract; antiparallel currents repel

monopole_dipole.title: Monopoles, Dipoles, and Field Comparisons
monopole_dipole.instructions: Synthesise your understanding of monopoles and dipoles across all field types.

sentences.text: Masses and single charges can exist as isolated {{d1}}, creating radial fields. Magnets cannot exist as isolated poles because {{d2}} have never been observed.

d2.tooltip: Which type of monopole does not exist?

sentences.text: An electric dipole consists of a {{d3}} and a {{d4}} charge separated by a distance. Its field pattern shows lines going {{d5}} directions.

d3.tooltip: One type of charge in an electric dipole

d4.tooltip: The other type of charge in an electric dipole

d5.tooltip: Lines point away from + and toward −

sentences.text: The fact that magnetic monopoles do not exist means every magnet has {{d6}} poles. Even at the atomic level, magnetic moments arise from {{d7}} electrons, which create dipole fields.

d6.tooltip: All magnets have N and S

d7.tooltip: What property of electrons creates magnetism?
